Tomato_Spider_mites_Two_spotted_spider_m.description: Tiny spider mites that feed on plant sap, causing yellow speckling on leaves and fine webbing.
Tomato_Spider_mites_Two_spotted_spider_m.treatment:
1. First, spray water with pressure on leaves to remove mites 
 2. Take 2-3 spoons of neem oil and mix in 1 bucket water
3. Add 1 spoon of washing soap to the mixture
4. Spray this on leaves early morning or evening
5. Cut and remove leaves with too many mites
6. If possible, release ladybugs in your field
7. Keep plants moist by spraying water
Tomato_Spider_mites_Two_spotted_spider_m.supplement: Pure Neem Oil (Green Bottle) - Natural Pesticide

Tomato_Late_blight.description: Severe fungal disease causing dark brown lesions on leaves, stems, and fruits.
Tomato_Late_blight.treatment:
1. Cut and burn all infected plant parts 
 2. Mix 1 small packet (2.5g) of blue powder in 1 bucket water
3. Spray when you first see brown spots
4. Keep 3 feet space between plants
5. Water only at plant base, not on leaves
6. Put dry leaves or straw around plants
7. Next time, buy disease-resistant seeds
8. Don't plant tomatoes in same place for 3 years

Tomato_Early_blight.description: Fungal disease causing dark spots with concentric rings on leaves.
Tomato_Early_blight.treatment:
1. Remove lower leaves with spots first
2. Mix 1 small packet (2g) of yellow powder in 1 bucket water
3. Spray every 7-10 days in morning
4. Use sticks to keep plants upright
5. Put dry leaves around plants
6. Cut extra branches for air flow
7. Use pipe or drip for watering
8. Clean tools with soap water

Tomato_Leaf_Mold.description: Fungal disease causing yellow spots and gray mold on leaves.
Tomato_Leaf_Mold.treatment:
1. Reduce water in air - this is important
2. Keep 3 feet space between plants
3. Remove leaves with mold
4. Cut extra branches for air
5. Water early morning only
6. Mix 1 packet bio-powder in water
7. Spray under leaves well
8. Use fan if in greenhouse

Tomato_Septoria_leaf_spot.description: Fungal disease causing circular spots with dark borders on leaves.
Tomato_Septoria_leaf_spot.treatment:
1. Start removing spotted leaves from bottom
2. Mix 1 small packet (2g) of white powder in 1 bucket water
3. Spray all over plant every 7 days
4. Put dry leaves or plastic on soil
5. Don't touch wet plants
6. Clean tools after use
7. Remove all dead leaves in fall
8. Use pipe for watering

Tomato_Bacterial_spot.description: Bacterial disease causing small dark spots on leaves and fruits.
Tomato_Bacterial_spot.treatment:
1. Remove bad plants if disease is bad
2. Mix 1 small packet (3g) of blue powder in 1 bucket water
3. Add 1/2 spoon white powder to prevent leaf burn
4. Spray early morning every 10 days
5. Don't water from top
6. Don't touch wet plants
7. Change crop place every 2 years
8. Clean sticks before reuse

Tomato_Tomato_YellowLeaf__Curl_Virus.description: Viral disease causing yellow and curled leaves with stunted growth.
Tomato_Tomato_YellowLeaf__Curl_Virus.treatment:
1. Remove and burn infected plants - no cure
2. Control white flies - they spread disease
3. Mix 2 spoons neem oil + 1/2 spoon soap in 1 bucket water
4. Spray under leaves early morning
5. Put yellow sticky paper near plants
6. Cover plants with fine net
7. Remove all weeds
8. Buy virus-resistant seeds next time
Tomato_Tomato_YellowLeaf__Curl_Virus.supplement: Neem + Karanj Oil Mix - Natural Pesticide

Tomato__Tomato_mosaic_virus.description: Viral disease causing mottled green patches on leaves.
Tomato__Tomato_mosaic_virus.treatment:
1. Remove infected plants - no cure
2. Clean tools with 2 caps in 1 bucket water
3. Wash hands with soap before touching plants
4. Control small insects with neem spray
5. Don't smoke near plants
6. Remove all weeds
7. Buy virus-resistant seeds
8. Don't save seeds from bad plants
Tomato__Tomato_mosaic_virus.supplement: Tool Cleaner Liquid - Safe for Plants

Tomato_healthy.description: Plant shows normal growth with healthy green leaves.
Tomato_healthy.treatment:
1. Water plants every morning
2. Add plant food every 2 weeks
3. Keep 2-3 feet space between plants
4. Put dry leaves around plants
5. Use sticks to support plants
6. Remove side shoots weekly
7. Check for insects regularly
8. Keep area clean

Pepper__bell___Bacterial_spot.description: Bacterial disease causing water-soaked spots on leaves and fruits that turn brown with yellow halos.
Pepper__bell___Bacterial_spot.treatment:
1. Mix 1 small packet (1g) of medicine in 10 buckets water
2. Add 1/2 spoon white powder
3. Spray early morning every 5 days
4. Remove bad leaves and fruits
5. Keep space between plants
6. Use pipe for watering
7. Change crop place every 3 years
8. Clean all tools

Pepper__bell___healthy.description: Plant shows normal growth with vibrant green leaves and no signs of disease.
Pepper__bell___healthy.treatment:
1. Water deeply 1-2 times weekly
2. Add plant food monthly
3. Keep 18-inch space between plants
4. Put dry leaves around plants
5. Support plants if heavy with fruits
6. Cut extra branches for air
7. Check for insects weekly
8. Keep area clean

Potato___Late_blight.description: Severe fungal disease causing water-soaked lesions on leaves, stems, and tubers.
Potato___Late_blight.treatment:
1. Mix 1 small packet (2g) in 1 bucket water
2. Spray when spots appear
3. Repeat every 7 days in rain
4. Remove and burn bad plants
5. Make sure water drains well
6. Keep space between rows
7. Check plants daily in rain
8. Harvest in dry weather

Potato___healthy.description: Plant shows healthy growth with green leaves and normal development.
Potato___healthy.treatment:
1. Add worm compost during planting
2. Keep 1 foot space between plants
3. Add soil around plants every 2-3 weeks
4. Water regularly but don't overwater
5. Remove weeds when small
6. Check for insect damage
7. Support plants if needed
8. Keep field clean

Tomato__Target_Spot.description: Fungal disease causing brown circular spots with concentric rings on leaves.
Tomato__Target_Spot.treatment:
1. Remove spotted leaves first
2. Mix 1 small bottle (1ml) in 1 bucket water
3. Spray all over plant
4. Repeat every 10 days if needed
5. Cut extra branches for air
6. Don't water from top
7. Clean fallen leaves regularly
8. Clean tools with soap

Apple___Apple_scab.description: Fungal disease causing olive-brown, velvety spots on leaves and fruit; leaves may distort and drop.
Apple___Apple_scab.treatment:
1. Remove and destroy fallen leaves and mummified fruit
2. Prune to open canopy and improve airflow
3. Apply protective fungicide (fixed copper or captan) at leaf-out and during wet periods
4. Plant resistant cultivars and avoid overhead irrigation

Apple___Black_rot.description: Fungal disease causing leaf spots with dark borders, limb cankers, and fruit rot.
Apple___Black_rot.treatment:
1. Prune out cankers 10–15 cm below diseased tissue
2. Remove mummified and rotting fruit
3. Improve sanitation and canopy airflow
4. Use captan or myclobutanil sprays during infection windows

Apple___Cedar_apple_rust.description: Rust fungus causing bright yellow/orange leaf spots with concentric rings; requires junipers as alternate host.
Apple___Cedar_apple_rust.treatment:
1. Remove nearby juniper galls if feasible
2. Plant resistant apple cultivars
3. Apply myclobutanil or trifloxystrobin at pink to petal-fall stages
4. Avoid overhead irrigation

Apple___healthy.description: Tree shows normal growth with clean, dark-green leaves and no lesions.
Apple___healthy.treatment:
1. Prune annually for open canopy
2. Water deeply but infrequently
3. Apply balanced fertilizer based on soil test
4. Maintain orchard sanitation

Blueberry___healthy.description: Plant has firm, glossy green leaves without spots or marginal burn.
Blueberry___healthy.treatment:
1. Keep soil acidic (pH 4.5–5.5)
2. Mulch with pine bark
3. Water consistently; avoid waterlogging
4. Fertilize lightly with acid-loving plant feed

Cherry_(including_sour)___Powdery_mildew.description: White, powdery fungal growth on upper leaf surfaces leading to distortion and premature drop.
Cherry_(including_sour)___Powdery_mildew.treatment:
1. Prune for airflow and remove infected shoots
2. Avoid excessive nitrogen
3. Apply sulfur or potassium bicarbonate early when symptoms appear
4. Choose tolerant varieties

Cherry_(including_sour)___healthy.description: Leaves are uniformly green, turgid, and free of spots or mildew.
Cherry_(including_sour)___healthy.treatment:
1. Maintain regular watering schedule
2. Balanced fertilization in spring
3. Annual pruning to open canopy
4. Mulch to conserve moisture

Corn_(maize)___Cercospora_leaf_spot Gray.description: Rectangular gray-tan lesions between leaf veins; progresses from lower canopy upward.
Corn_(maize)___Cercospora_leaf_spot Gray.treatment:
1. Rotate crops and manage residue
2. Plant resistant hybrids
3. Apply strobilurin/triazole fungicide at VT–R1 if disease risk is high
4. Avoid dense planting in humid regions

Corn_(maize)___Common_rust_.description: Cinnamon-brown, oval pustules on both leaf surfaces; can coalesce under cool, moist conditions.
Corn_(maize)___Common_rust_.treatment:
1. Use resistant hybrids
2. Scout early; treat if threshold exceeded
3. Apply triazole/strobilurin mixes during tasseling if severe
4. Rotate crops to reduce inoculum

Corn_(maize)___Northern_Leaf_Blight.description: Long, cigar-shaped gray-green lesions that turn tan; spreads in cool, humid weather.
Corn_(maize)___Northern_Leaf_Blight.treatment:
1. Plant resistant hybrids
2. Rotate with non-hosts and manage residue
3. Apply fungicide at VT–R1 if disease threatens yield
4. Improve field airflow

Corn_(maize)___healthy.description: Leaves are uniformly green with no lesions; plants show steady growth.
Corn_(maize)___healthy.treatment:
1. Use balanced NPK based on soil test
2. Irrigate to avoid stress at tasseling and grain fill
3. Scout for foliar diseases
4. Manage weeds and residue

Grape___Black_rot.description: Tan leaf spots with dark margins and black fruit mummies; circular lesions on canes and leaves.
Grape___Black_rot.treatment:
1. Remove mummified clusters and infected shoots
2. Train and prune to increase airflow
3. Apply captan or myclobutanil at pre-bloom through bunch closure
4. Maintain vineyard sanitation

Grape___Esca_(Black_Measles).description: Chronic trunk disease: tiger-stripe leaf chlorosis/necrosis with berry spotting; no reliable chemical cure.
Grape___Esca_(Black_Measles).treatment:
1. Remove infected cordons/trunks; retrain from healthy shoots
2. Minimize pruning wounds and protect large cuts
3. Reduce plant stress and improve irrigation
4. Replace severely affected vines

Grape___Leaf_blight_(Isariopsis_Leaf_Spo.description: Angular to irregular brown lesions on leaves; thrives in warm, humid conditions.
Grape___Leaf_blight_(Isariopsis_Leaf_Spo.treatment:
1. Improve canopy airflow by proper pruning
2. Remove infected leaves
3. Apply copper or bio-fungicides preventively
4. Avoid overhead irrigation

Grape___healthy.description: Vines with healthy, turgid leaves and no spotting or mildew.
Grape___healthy.treatment:
1. Train and prune annually
2. Maintain drip irrigation and mulching
3. Balanced nutrition based on tissue tests
4. Monitor pests and diseases regularly

Orange___Haunglongbing_(Citrus_greening).description: Bacterial disease causing blotchy leaf mottling, yellow shoots, small misshapen fruit; spread by psyllids; no cure.
Orange___Haunglongbing_(Citrus_greening).treatment:
1. Remove and destroy infected trees
2. Control Asian citrus psyllid with insecticides and traps
3. Use certified disease-free planting material
4. Maintain tree health to slow decline

Peach___Bacterial_spot.description: Angular, water-soaked leaf spots that turn brown and tear; fruit pitting and cracking.
Peach___Bacterial_spot.treatment:
1. Plant tolerant varieties
2. Reduce nitrogen that promotes lush growth
3. Apply copper or oxytetracycline during high-risk periods
4. Avoid overhead irrigation

Peach___healthy.description: Leaves are green, free from lesions or curl; shoots vigorous and balanced.
Peach___healthy.treatment:
1. Prune to an open center
2. Irrigate deeply during fruit set
3. Apply balanced fertilizer per soil test
4. Thin fruits to improve size and health

Pepper,_bell___Bacterial_spot.description: Small, water-soaked leaf spots become brown with yellow halos; fruit may show scabby lesions.
Pepper,_bell___Bacterial_spot.treatment:
1. Remove infected leaves and avoid handling when wet
2. Use copper sprays at first sign
3. Rotate 2–3 years and avoid contaminated seed
4. Water at soil level, not overhead

Pepper,_bell___healthy.description: Plant shows uniform, glossy green leaves and strong stems.
Pepper,_bell___healthy.treatment:
1. Provide consistent moisture and mulch
2. Fertilize lightly during flowering
3. Stake heavy plants
4. Scout for bacterial and fungal spots

Potato___Early_blight.description: Dark brown lesions with concentric rings on older leaves; yellowing and defoliation in dry periods.
Potato___Early_blight.treatment:
1. Remove lower infected foliage
2. Apply protectant fungicides (mancozeb/chlorothalonil) preventively
3. Rotate crops and manage residue
4. Avoid overhead irrigation

Raspberry___healthy.description: Canes are vigorous with dark-green, blemish-free leaves.
Raspberry___healthy.treatment:
1. Tie canes to improve airflow
2. Mulch and irrigate consistently
3. Prune out old fruiting canes
4. Monitor for cane blights

Soybean___healthy.description: Leaves are uniformly green with no foliar lesions; canopy closes evenly.
Soybean___healthy.treatment:
1. Inoculate seed where needed
2. Fertilize per soil test
3. Scout for foliar diseases at R1–R3
4. Rotate crops to manage pathogens

Squash___Powdery_mildew.description: White, powdery patches on upper leaf surfaces; common in warm, dry conditions with humid nights.
Squash___Powdery_mildew.treatment:
1. Plant resistant varieties and space for airflow
2. Remove severely infected leaves
3. Apply sulfur or potassium bicarbonate at first sign
4. Avoid overhead irrigation in evening

Strawberry___Leaf_scorch.description: Small purple spots that develop tan centers and may coalesce, leading to scorched appearance.
Strawberry___Leaf_scorch.treatment:
1. Remove old leaves after harvest
2. Improve spacing and airflow
3. Apply captan or bio-fungicides preventively
4. Avoid overhead irrigation

Strawberry___healthy.description: Plants have bright, glossy leaves with no spots; vigorous crowns and runners.
Strawberry___healthy.treatment:
1. Mulch with straw or plastic
2. Fertigate lightly during bloom and fruiting
3. Remove old leaves post-harvest
4. Monitor for leaf spots and mites

Tomato___Bacterial_spot.description: Small, water-soaked leaf spots with yellow halos; fruit develops scabby lesions.
Tomato___Bacterial_spot.treatment:
1. Remove infected leaves and avoid working when plants are wet
2. Apply copper bactericides regularly during outbreaks
3. Rotate crops and use certified seed
4. Irrigate at soil level

Tomato___Early_blight.description: Dark lesions with concentric rings on older leaves; yellowing and defoliation.
Tomato___Early_blight.treatment:
1. Remove lower infected foliage
2. Spray with mancozeb or chlorothalonil at first symptoms
3. Stake/prune to improve airflow
4. Rotate and mulch to reduce splash

Tomato___Late_blight.description: Rapid, water-soaked lesions with white fuzz under cool, humid conditions; fruit rot common.
Tomato___Late_blight.treatment:
1. Remove and destroy infected plants immediately
2. Apply systemic + protectant fungicides during outbreaks
3. Avoid overhead irrigation and reduce leaf wetness
4. Space plants for airflow

Tomato___Leaf_Mold.description: Yellow patches on upper leaf surface with olive-gray mold below; thrives in high humidity.
Tomato___Leaf_Mold.treatment:
1. Ventilate greenhouse and reduce humidity
2. Remove infected leaves
3. Apply bio-fungicides or copper preventively
4. Water early morning only

Tomato___Septoria_leaf_spot.description: Small circular spots with dark margins and light centers; begins on lower leaves.
Tomato___Septoria_leaf_spot.treatment:
1. Remove lower leaves as spots appear
2. Apply chlorothalonil/copper weekly in wet weather
3. Mulch to reduce soil splash
4. Avoid overhead irrigation

Tomato___Spider_mites Two-spotted_spider.description: Speckled, yellowing leaves with fine webbing; mites feed on undersides of leaves.
Tomato___Spider_mites Two-spotted_spider.treatment:
1. Spray leaves with water to knock mites off
2. Use neem oil or insecticidal soap under leaves
3. Remove heavily infested leaves
4. Keep plants well-watered to reduce stress

Tomato___Target_Spot.description: Brown circular lesions with concentric rings; can cause defoliation in warm, humid weather.
Tomato___Target_Spot.treatment:
1. Remove infected leaves
2. Apply propiconazole or copper preventively
3. Improve airflow by pruning
4. Avoid frequent overhead watering

Tomato___Tomato_Yellow_Leaf_Curl_Virus.description: Virus causing upward leaf curling, yellowing, and stunted plants; spread by whiteflies.
Tomato___Tomato_Yellow_Leaf_Curl_Virus.treatment:
1. Remove infected plants (no cure)
2. Control whiteflies with yellow traps and neem/insecticides
3. Use resistant varieties and virus-free transplants
4. Exclude with fine mesh netting

Tomato___Tomato_mosaic_virus.description: Mottled, mosaic leaf pattern with distortion; virus is highly persistent and spread mechanically.
Tomato___Tomato_mosaic_virus.treatment:
1. Remove infected plants (no cure)
2. Disinfect tools and wash hands before handling
3. Control pests that cause wounds
4. Use resistant cultivars and avoid tobacco handling

Tomato___healthy.description: Leaves are uniformly green with no spots; plants are vigorous and flowering normally.
Tomato___healthy.treatment:
1. Stake or cage for airflow
2. Water at soil level; mulch to reduce splash
3. Fertilize lightly but regularly
4. Scout weekly for pests and diseases
